required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Intubation Duration Between Rapid Sequence Intubation (RSI) Technique and Non-RSI Technique
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Intubation Duration Between Rapid Sequence Intubation Technique and Non- Rapid Sequence Intubation Technique in Siriraj Hospital by Emergency Medicine Residences

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate intubation duration between rapid sequence intubation technique (RSI) and non-rapid sequence intubation technique (non-RSI) performed by emergency medicine residents in Siriraj hospital.

detailed_description.textblock: A prospective cohort study was conducted in the non-traumatic emergency department (ED).

primary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the overall intubation duration until confirmation the endotracheal position, an expected average of 2 minutes
primary_outcome.description: The overall intubation duration is recorded on the decision to intubation patient and corresponds to the time of confirmation the endotracheal position by chest auscultation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the intubation duration until confirmation the endotracheal position, an expected average of 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The intubation duration (Ti), it is defined from application the laryngoscope into the patient's mouth to the time of confirmation an endotracheal position

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed in the period of staying in the emergency room and hospital, an expected average of 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Complications occur during and after intubation peroid are recorded and monitored until patients are discharged fromt the hospital.

arm_group.description: Intubation with RSI technique. RSI technique includes the administration of inductive and neuromuscular blocking agents to facilitate an intubation. In this study, we have no restriction of medication use. Physicians can chose any of medication as an individual judgement.
Intubation without RSI technique. No any medication use during intubation period.

intervention.description: All medications are administered only one dose before intubation Anesthetics: Propofol 2-2.5 mg/kg Thiopental 3-5mg/kg Etomidate 1-2mg/kg Neuromuscular blocking agents: Succinylcholine 1-1.5mg/kg Rocuronium 0.9mg/kg Opioid: Fentanyl 1-2ug/kg

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients required airway control by tracheal intubation
Exclusion Criteria:
- cardiac arrest
